verses.text: May your father and mother be glad; may she who gave you birth rejoice!

rsbNotes.title: Pr 22:17–24:22
rsbNotes.text: 22:17–24:22 This section is a collection of wisdom sayings mainly in the form of instructions (Introduction: Characteristics and Themes). There is evidence that the first part (22:17–23:11) has drawn upon the Egyptian wisdom of Amenemope (cf. 4:1–27 note). If so, these insights have been consciously appropriated as admonitions that assist one in meeting covenant obligations to “trust . . . in the Lord” (22:19). The author of Proverbs, like the historians of the Bible, was not prevented in principle from using existing materials in the course of writing what God inspired.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 23:22–25
rsbNotes.text: 23:22–25 Instructions to children on right family relationships. These principles are derived from the fifth commandment (Ex. 20:12) and testified to by the sages’ discerning observation of harmonious and joyful human relationships.

verses.text: My son, give me your heart and let your eyes keep to my ways,

rsbNotes.title: Pr 23:26–28
rsbNotes.text: 23:26–28 A warning against immoral women (2:16–19; 5:1–20).

rsbNotes.title: Pr 23:26
rsbNotes.text: 23:26 give me your heart. That is, pay attention (2:2 note). The wisdom teachers call for undivided attention and trust in their teaching.

verses.text: for a prostitute is a deep pit and a wayward wife is a narrow well.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 23:27
rsbNotes.text:
23:27 deep pit. The image is of a pit for trapping wild animals.

adulteress. Lit. “a foreign woman,” a term used for immoral or adulterous persons (2:16 note).

narrow well. Impossible to escape from (Jer. 38:6).

verses.text: Like a bandit she lies in wait, and multiplies the unfaithful among men.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 23:28
rsbNotes.text: 23:28 traitors. Lit. “treacherous,” here signifying unfaithfulness in marriage.
